content.rendered:
“How sweet are thy words unto my taste! yea, sweeter than honey to my mouth!” — Psalm 119:103 (KJV)

It’s coming up on the eleventh anniversary of the date that I asked Sandy to marry me. We were wed on January 23, 2022. Soon after, we were told that Sandy had stage four cancer. Sandy went home to be with her Heavenly Father on March 6, 2022.

Yet, even before we were married, we had chosen a small journal and had begin writing love notes to each other. These were short notes that expressed our feelings for each other.

I would like to encourage keep a journal. If you don’t have someone you can share a journal, you can keep one for yourself. I often write about my relationship with the living God. If you are dating or are married, you may want to consider keeping a journal with that other person. If you have a child, you might keep one for him or her.

The Bible is God’s love letter to us. It’s filled with stories of people that God used and how, in the future, God will glorify his son. It tells us that “…God so loved the world, that he gave his only begotten Son, that whosoever believeth in him should not perish, but have everlasting life.” — John 3:16 (KJV)

“But God, who is rich in mercy, for his great love wherewith he loved us, Even when we were dead in sins, hath quickened us together with Christ, (by grace ye are saved;)” — Ephesians 2:4-5 (KJV)

God’s love is never ending because God is love (1 John 4:8) Yet, there comes a time when our opportunity to receive God’s love comes to an end. “Seek ye the Lord while he may be found, call ye upon him while he is near.” — Isaiah 55:6

Notes are just one way you can show your love for those in your life. It’s not the quality of the journal that shows how much you love someone. It’s the thought that goes into the words that you pen on its pages.
